then everything in the world will have no merit.
And if one understands that East and West are the opposites of each other but cannot be without each other
then the distribution of merit is determined. [Merit is always complementary.??]
From the point of view of subjectivity
when on the basis of whatever one finds so-and-so one considers that to be (actually) so-and-so
then all these things in the world will be so;
and if one the basis of whatever one considers not to be so-and-so one takes them actually not to be so-and-so,
then all these things in the world will not be so-and-so.
Once one has understood how Yao and Jie each consider themselves right and consider each other wrong,
then treatment of subjectivity has come into view.
In ancient times Shun succeeded Yao when the latter abdicated,
and Zhi cut off the succession after Kuai abdicated in his favour.
Tang and Wu struggled and became kinds,
Duke Bai struggled and was destroyed.
From this it appears
that the ritual practice competitive struggle and of ritual abdication
and the conduct of Yao and Jie
count as noble or base at given times only
and that nobility and baseness of action cannot be taken to be constant features.
With a big beam you can ram a city wall
but you cannot block a gap:
that is to say one makes different use of tools.
Thoroughbreds like Qiji and Hualiu
can race along for a thousand leagues in a single day,
but for the catching mice these are no match for a wildcat:
that is to say they differ with regard to their skills.
that is to say it differs with regard to its inborn capacities.
The owl catches fleas at night
and distinguishes a minute hair
but in the daytime it may open its fierce eyes wide
and still fails to see a mound or a mountain (right before it):
Therefore it is said:
So apparently one faithfully agrees with what (one considers) is right and disrgards what (one considers) is wrong,
one faithfully conforms with (what one considers) the principles of good government and disregards what (one considers to be) the principles of misrule?
But such an attitude is not to understand the prinicples of Heaven and Earth,
and the dynamic essence of all the things of this world;
this is like faithfully conforming to Heaven and disregarding Earth,
faithfully conforming to Yin and disregarding Yang:
it is clear that these methods canot be successfully implemented.
Moreover, if one keeps talking along these lines and does not give up (these kinds of dichotomies)
then if not stupid one is misguided.
Emperors and kings differ in their practice of abdicating,
the Three Dynasties differ in their practice of succession.
Those who fail to be in accordance with their times
and who go against current custom
are called usurping individuals;
those who keep in accordance with their times
and follow current custom
are called adherents of duty.
Be quiet, Lord of the Yellow River.
How could you ever understand the first thing about nobility and baseness
about the unimportant and the important?"
The Lord of the Yellow River said: Well, in that case, what am I to do
and what am I to avoid doing?
And as for my refusing or accepting, opting for and rejecting
how, in the end, am I to handle this?"
Ruo of the Northern Sea said:
"From the perspective of the Way
what counts as noble, what as base?
These are just endless categorial regurgitations.
Never inhibit your aspirations,
so as to run completely counter to the Way!
What counts as many, what as few?
These are just arithmentic iterations.
Never be unambiguous in your conduct,
so as to be all at odds with the Way!
Quite stern you have to be, as when a state has a ruler
who never shows any private favour;
Quite loftily serene you have to be, as when the sacrifices have their altar of the land,
and not dole out private blessings;
you must be all-embracing in every way, inexhaustible like the Four Directions
so as to have no boundaries of any kind.
You must cherish all the creatures of the world:
which of them should you sustain and keep under your wings?
This method is called Being Without Preferred Method.
All things are one and on one level:
which of them should be deficient, which superior?
The Way does not decline and renewal:
things die and get born.
and you should not bet on their successful development;
they are at one point deficient, at another point plentiful,
they do not have a fixed place for their shape.
Years cannot be taken up from the beginning,
seasons cannot be stopped in their progress:
things ebb and flow, the fill up and drain out
and when they come to their end there is a new beginning.
This is the basis on which one talks (loosely) about the
and on which one lays out the principles of all the things of the world.
The life of things
is like the (short) gallop of a horse:
there is no movement during which they do not undergo change,
and there is no time at which they are not displaced.
What to do?
What not to do?
These things are certainly going to transform themselves."
The Lord of the Yellow River said: "Well then: what is so precious in this Way?"
Ruo of the Northern Sea said:
"He who understands the way is bound to reach out to the principles of things
he who reaches out to the principles of things will be clear about the relative significance of things
and he who is clear about the relative significance things
will not harm himself for the sake for (mere) things.
As for someone who has perfectly realised his natural potential
fire is incapable of heating him up
water is incapable of drowning him,
the cold and the heat is incapable of harming him,
birds and beasts are incapable of ruining him.
This does not mean that the person who has perfectly realised his natural potential considers these things as harmless:
it is to say that he has a clear vision of where to find peace and what to regard as dangerous,
and that he is at ease with misfortune and good fortune.
He does take care to avoid one and work toward the other,
but neither misfortune nor good fortune can harm him.
Therefore it is said:
"Heaven is inside one
human affairs are outside one,
and one's natural potential resides in Heaven.
If one understands human conduct
one bases oneself on Heaven
and therein resides one's success.
Being indecisive one bends and stretches (to stay in tune with circumstances)
one goes back to what is crucial and one talks about what is ultimately relevant."
"What, then do you call from Heaven,
and what human?"
Ruo from the Northern Sea said:
"Oxen and horses have four feet:
that is the work of Heaven;
pulling down a halter over a horse's head,
piercing an ox's nose,
that is called the work of man.
Therefore it is said:
never destroy what is the work of Heaven by the works of men,
never destroy the work of fate by the act of of your reasoning,
never be desperate after fame through your successes.
Take good care of what you have and make sure you do not lose it
this is what is called reverting to one's veritable essence."
The one-legged dragon envies the millipede,
the millipede envies the snake,
the snake envies the wind (for speed?),
the wind envies the eye (for being properly focussed),
and the eye envies the mind (for having a higher more abstract focus).
So the one-legged dragon said to the millipede:
"With one leg I hobble along
and I'm just no good.
But now you, how on earth do you get handle your myriads of feet?"
The millipede said:
"No, no, no!
Haven't you seen those people who spit?
When they splash it out the large drops are big as pearls
and the minute ones are fine as mist:
countless they are, these drops, as they drop all scrambled.
Now I, personally, just activate the impulse from Heaven in me.
and I have no idea how all this is as it is."
The millipede said to the snake:
"I move along with my plethora of feet,
but I'm not doing as well as you are doing with no feet at all:
How is that?"
The snake said:
"Well look! What the impulse from Heaven initiates
how can that be changed?
Why the hell should I need any feet?"
The snake said to the wind:
"I just move along by wriggling my backbone and my ribs,
and I'm doing just fine.
But you, rising in a complete mess in the Northern Sea
you rumble on into the Southern Sea,
as if all this was nothing to you:
How is that?"
The wind said:
"You're quite right.
I do rise in a complete mess in the Northern Sea
and then do enter the Southern Sea:
and yet, you point a finger at me and you have won the upper hand against me,
you just step on me and you have outdone me.
But be that as it may,
when it comes to breaking a big tree to pieces
or toppling a large building
only I am capable of that.
And so it is that I turn a large number of small failures to win
into one large victory.
Turning things into one large victory
that is something only the sage can do."
Confucius was travelling in Kuang,
when the Song surrounded him with several armed platoons,
but the man strummed his zither and sang his song as if nothing was happening.
Zilu went in to see him
and he said:
"Why is our Master so happy (when is such obvious trouble)?"
Confucius said:
"Come here!
Let me tell you!
For a long time I've tried to stay clear of serious trouble
and when I am unable to avoid it, that is due to fate;
for a long time I have sought to become accomplished
and when I do not get my way that is due to the conditions of the times.
During the times of Yao and Shun no one was in inextricable distress in the world,
but that is not because their intelligence succeeded;
during the times of Jie and Zhou
there was no one in the world who was accomplished,
and that was no because their intelligence failed them:
it was in both cases the circumstances of the times that happened to bring things about.
When travelling by water not to keep one's distance from its scaly monsters
that is the prowess of the fishermen;
when travelling by land not not to keep one's distance from its rhinos and tigers
that is the prowess of the hunters;
when the drawn swords are crossed right in front of one
to be indifferent to life or death,
that is the prowess of the military élite;
being aware that inextricable distress is a matter of fate
and that accomplishments are a matter of the times,
facing great challenges fearlessly,
that is the prowess of the sage.
You just relax, my friend:
there is something that controls my destiny.
After some time
the leader of the armoured platoon stepped forward
and he explained what had happened:
"I thought you were Yang Hu
and that is why we were surrounding you.
Now that you aren't the man
I beg to take my leave and to withdraw (my forces)."
Gongsun Long asked Mou from Wei:
"As a young man I studied the Way of the Former Kings
and as I grew up I got to understand clearly conduct in accordance with benevolence and duty.
I coordinated sameness and difference
I separated the hard from the white;
what is so from what is not so,
what is acceptable from what is not;
I exacerbated on the knowledge of all the schools of thought
and I exhausted the arguments of all the participants in the discussions:
I fancied that I had achieved the ultimate insights.
Now I have heard the words of Zhuangzi
and I am all mystified and amazed:
I never know whether it is that the discourse does not quite get there
or whether my understanding is unable to live up to Zhuangzi's words.
Now I have nothing to speak up with my silly beak,
and I take the liberty to ask to be instructed on your methods."
Prince Mou leant on his armrest and heaved a heavy sigh
he threw back his head and said with a chuckle:
"Have you never heard of the frog in the abandoned well pit?
He told the turtle of the Eastern Sea:
"Aren't I happy?
I hop about on the rim of my pit
and then I slip into a corner where a brick is missing;
I throw myself into the water so it supports my armpits and my chin,
I sink myself into the mud so I make my feet my feet disappear right up to my ankles,
I look around, and the mosquitoes, the little crabs, the tadpoles
none of these can reach my level of joy.
And now, the joys of commanding the waters of a whole gulley bestriding an abandoned well pit
these are surely the ultimate!
Why don't you, Master, come over from time to time to come in and see the delights?"
The turtle from the Eastern Sea had not yet got her left foot into the pit
when her right knee had already got firmly stuck.
So at that point the turtle manoeuvered back and withdrew
and then told the frog:
"The sea is thousands of leagues away,
one could not possibly specify how large it;
it is a thousand spans deep
and one could not possibly fathom its depth.
During the times of Yu there were floods in nine years out of then
but the waters of the Eastern Sea would not for that reason rise;
During the times of Tang there were droughts in seven years out of eight,
but the shores of that Eastern Sea did not recede for that reason.
Now not to budge in any way for any time, short or long,
not to move forward or to withdraw backward because there is more or less of anything
this surely is the great delight of the Eastern Sea."
At this point, when the frog in his abandoned well pit heard this,
he was staggered, aghast:
he was quite simply beyond himself.
The fact is that when your intellect does not understand the realm of right and wrong
and you still wish to gain an overall view of Zhuangzi's words,
that is like trying to get a mosquito to carry a mountain,
or a bill to race across the Yangzi river:
they are bound not to be up to their task.
The fact is that when your intelligence does not know how to discuss the the most superb words,
and you adapt yourself to what is profitable to you at one point of time
is that not to be a frog in an abandoned well?
Now that man (Zhuangzi) is at this time treading the Yellow Springs
but he is rising up to the Great Sovereign (Heaven):
he has no south, no north:
spreading himself out he fans out in all directions,
and he dives into the unfathomable;
he has no east, no west:
he takes the utter mystery as his starting point
and reverts to the comprehensive understanding.
When you then simply go ahead and seek an understanding of him
you seek him out through argumentation,
that is like surveying the sky looking through a tube
use an awl to point at Earth:
surely your range is too small.
You go your way!
Moreover: have you really never heard about Yuzi from Shouling learning to walk properly in Handan?
Now that man never got to learn the art (of walking) of that state
but in addition he lost his old natural way of walking:
so he just went home crawling on all fours.
If you don't get away now
you'll forget what you've always known
and you will forget whatever competence you had."
Gongsun Long's jaw dropped and he he was unable to close his mouth,
his tongue rose (as if he was about to speak and would not go down again,
and then he slipped away and fled.
Zhuangzi was angling on the River Pu
when the King of Chu send two dignitaries to go along and take the intiative
to say:
"It is my hope to bother you with (the government of) my entire territory."
Zhuangzi held onto his fishing rod, never to look at the visitors
and he said:
"I have heard that in Chu there is divine tortoise:
it had died at the age of 3000 years.
The king wrapped it up and put it into a basket and kept in in the ancestral temple.
Now this tortoise,
would it prefer to die, subsist as a pile of bones and be honoured
or would it prefer to drag its tail in the mud?"
The two dignitaries said:
"It would prefer to drag its tail in the mud."
Zhuangzi said:
"Off you go!
I shall drag my tail in the mud!"
Huizi was prime minister in Liang
and Zhuangzi went to visit him.
Someone told Huizi:
"Zhuangzi has arrived.
and he wants to take over your position as a prime minister."
At that point Huizi was terrified
and for three days and three nights he ran a campaign lo look for the man.
Zhuangzi went along to look him up
and said:
"In the south there is a bird
called the yuanchu:
you may know about it.
Now that yuanchu sets out from the Southern Sea
and it flies on to the Northern Sea
it will only rest on a wutong tree
it will only eat the fruit of the lian tree
it will only drink from the sweet water sources.
Now there was an owl who had got ahold of rotten rat
and when the yuanchu happened to pass by
the owl looked up, gave him a stare and said:
'Shoo!'
Are you now trying
to shoo! me with that state with its capital in Liang?"
Zhuangzi was wandering on the bridge over the River Hao
Zhuangzi said:
"The are out swimming along at their ease
this is the joy of the fish."
Huizi said:
"You are not a fish
whence do you know the joys of a fish?"
Zhuangzi said:
"(Very well, but) you are not I
so how do you know that I do not understand the joys of the fish?"
Huizi said:
"I'm not you
and difinitely I do not understand you,
but (by the same token) you definitely are not the fish
and thus you do not understand the joy of the fish, quod erat demonstrandum."
Zhuangzi said:
"Please let us get back to the basics:
when you said:
'whence you know the joys of the fish?'
you knew I knew it and asked me whence:
let me tell you whence: I know it from here, by the river Hao."
The Ultimate Joy
Is there ultimate joy in this world or is there not?
Is there something that gives true life to the person or is there not?
Now: what to do? What to rely on?
What to avoid? What to settle for?
What to go for? What to stay clear of?
What to enjoy? What to hate?
Now what they prize highly
is wealth, noble status, long life, being appreciated;
what everyone enjoys
is for the body to be at ease, sumptuous meals, handsome dress, physical attractiveness, musical tunes;
what they despise
is poverty, low status, early death, being hated.
what they find hard to bear
is for one's person not to find rest,
for the mouth to get sumptuous meals,
for one's body not to get handsome dress to wear
for one's eyes not to get attractive beauty to see,
for the ears not to get fine tunes to hear:
when anyone does not get these things
he will be all upset and fearful:
this surely is a stupid way of going about one's body.
Now the rich
wear out their persons so that diseases will arise,
they pile up goods and can never get to use them all:
this is a merely external way of going about the body.
The people of noble status
will beaver away until late at night,
pondering what is the right thing to do and what not:
this is surely a thoughtless way of going about the body.
When man is born
he is born together with worry,
during his long life he is all confused,
forever worrying and actually not getting to die:
How utterly unbearable!
this is a way of going about the body
Illlustrious men are approved of by everyone
but that is not quite sufficient to guarantee their own survival.
I'm not so sure whether being approved of is a good thing or perhaps a bad thing.
If one is to take it to be a good thing
(the fact remains) it is not suffient to guarantee their own survival;
and if one is to take it (being approved of, taken to be good) as not a good thing
(the fact remains) that it does guarantee the survival of people.
Thus it is said:
"When one's devoted remonstration is not accepted
discreetly with draw and do not put up a fight."
Zixu put up a fight and had his body mangled:
had he not put up a fight
he would never have made a name for himself (in the first place).
Is there really such a thing as 'the right thing to do' or isn't there?
What the common people nowadays work towards and what they find joy in
I am, there again, not so sure whether this 'joy' is really joyful
or ultimately unenjoyable.
As I observe what the common people enjoy
and how they hold up all the exciting things,
desperately busy as if they were going to have no choice,
and how they all say: 'what a joy!'
I don't really enjoy this at all,
nor do I not enjoy it:
is there, ultimately, 'the enjoyable', or is there no such thing?
I consider indifference as the true joy,
and that is again what the common people find unbearable.
And so it is said:
"In the ultimate joy there is no joy,
in the ultimate praise there is no praise."
Right and wrong in this world cannot ultimately be determined
But all the same
by indifference one can determine 'right' and 'wrong'.
The ultimate joy gives stable life to a person,
but only non-interference can get close to preserve this life.
Let me try putting it this way:
Heaven is indifferent and thereby it is clear,
Earth is indifferent and thereby at rest:
thus these two, through indifference play together
and all things of the world are transformed and generated.
wondrously, marvellously
these things arise out of nothing!
Marvellously, wondrously
what was nothing takes on a form!
All creatures of the world fulfill their functions
practicing non-interference they thrive.
Therefore it is said:
Heaven and earth are detached in action,
but there is nothing they do not bring about.
Who of the mortals can reach this level of detachment?
When Zhuangzi's wife had died
Huizi offered his condolences
and Zhuangzi at that point was squatting on the ground using a pot as a drum and (happily) singing away.
Huizi said: She lived with you, took care of your children, grew old with you:
for you not to lament her when she has died is bad enough,
but to use a pot as a drum and sing happily away
that surely is too much!"
Zhuangzi said:
"No, no!
Just after she died
how could I fail to be moved?
But when I found that at the outset she never lived at all
and not only did she not live,
there was originally no body of hers at all;
and not only was there no body of hers
she there was no vital force of hers.
She was mixed in the wondrous realm of things.
Then things changed and she developed a vital force,
the vital force changed so she got to have a physical body,
the physical body changed and she got to have life,
and now, again, she changed and she moved into death:
all this taken together constitutes the natural progress of the years, and the four seasons.
Now when this person will sleep at ease in in the Grand Mansion
then for me to go bawling and mewling behind and wailing for her
this I considered would be a failure to fully grasp human destiny,
so I desisted."
Zhi Lishu and Hua Jieshu were surveying the Mounds of the Mysterious Lord
the ruins at Kunlun
where the Yellow Emperor found his repose.
Suddenly, a willowtree sprouted forth from Hua Jieshu's left elbow:
in his mind he was all upset and resented this (unmotivated growth).
Zhili Shu said: "You resent this?
Hua Jieshu said: "No way! What should I resent?
Our life is on loan:
we borrow it and that which creates our life
is mere dust.
Death and life are our day and night,
and moreover you and I we are observing (theorein) the transmogrification of things,
and when the transmogrification reaches myself
why should I go on to be resentful."
Zhuangzi went to Chu
and he noticed an empty skull:
all parched, it barely maintained its shape.
he patted it with his horse whip
and then went on to interrogate it:
saying:
Sir, craving life have you lost sight of principle
so as to become this?
Or perhaphs have you had trouble losing a state
or being executed by the axe of the law
so you've become this?
Or perhaps you've been guilty of inappropriate conduct of affairs
and ashamed to bring discredit upon your father and mother, wife and children
you have become this?
Or perhaps you were exposed to the horrors of frost and hunger
so you've ended up like this?
Or perhaps because of advanced age
have you become this?"
Then having stopped talking
he pulled the skull towards him
and fell asleep with his head on that skull.
At midnight
the skull appeared to him in a dream and said:
"Your chatter is like that of the sophists,
everthing you are holding forth on
are the prejudices of the living,
but we, the dead, will have nothing of this.
Do you want to learn about the theories of the dead?"
Zhuangzi replied: "Yes, please."
The skull said:
Once you have died
there is no ruler above,
and no inferior below you
you certainly have no work relating to the four seasons
following the course of things your seasons are those of the Universe:
even the joys of facing south and ruling as a king
cannot match this."
Zhuangzi would have none of this
and he said:
"Suppose I order the Lord of Destinies
to give life to your body again
and make you into a creature with bones, muscle, sinew and skin,
and return to you your father, your mother, your children and your neighbours and acquaintances
would you find that desirable?"
The skull gave a profound frown, turned up its nose and said:
"Why should I have it in me to give up the joys of a king on his throne
to return to slogging away in the world of the living?"
Yan Yuan was going to turn east and move to Qi
and Confucius looked worried.
Zigong rose from his mat and asked:
"May I ask:
Just because our Yan Yuan is going East to Qi you, Master, look worried. Why might that be?"
Confucius said: "Good question you ask there!
In former ties Guanzi had a saying on this
and I much approve of it:
'If a bag is small, it is not going to hold large things,
if a line is short it is not going to reach deep down into the water.'
This being so,
I fancy that fate has certain things it can bring about
and bodies are certain things are fit for:
these limitations one cannot do anything about.
I am terrified that together with the Marquis of Qi
our Yan Hui will pontificate about the Way of the Yellow Emperor
and then go on about the sayings of Suiren
and Shennong.
That Marquis is then going to try to find such talents in himself
and he will not find them,
and not finding them he will be all disorientated,
and when men are disorientated then death is the result.
Could it be that you've never heard about this one?
In ancient times a bird from the seas slighted in the suburbs of Lu
and the Marquis of Lu bid it formally welcome in the ancestral shrine:
he had the Nine Shao performed in front of it for pleasure
and he set up the tailao ritual to provide its delicacies for it.
But the bird at that point stared gloomily
did not dare to eat the slightest slice of meat
did not dare to drink a single glass of drink
so after three days the bird was dead.
This is to feed a bird on what would feed you,
it is not to feed a bird on what feeds a bird.
Now for feeding a bird with what feeds a bird
the thing to do is to let him perch in the deep forst
to let him roam in the muddly islets
and to let him float along on the rivers and lakes,
feed him eel and minnow,
let him follow his swarm in line and settle down (together with them),
and wriggles through existence.
That creature hates to so much as the sound of human speech,
nor does he care in the least for this twaddle and babble of our times.
The (formidable) music of the Xianchi and Jiushao Odes,
if you make a show of these on the steppes,
then the birds, hearing this, will fly off,
the beasts, hearing this, will run away,
the fishes, hearing this, will dive deep,
but the human crowd, hearing this
will converge together and enjoy the show.
Fish will thrive in water,
humans will drown in water:
those creatures will differ from one another
and their likes and dislikes are inherently different from each other.
That is why the former sages did not focus their talents on one and the same thing,
and they did not made the same thing their business.
Names fulfill their purpose in the reality they refer to
rectitude is established by the fittingning to what is right.

MOUNTAIN TREES
Zhuangzi was taking a walk in the mountains
where he saw a large tree:
the branches and leaves were thriving and burgeoning,
but a woodcutter was resting by its side
and was by no means picking it out for his purposes.
Zhuangzi asked the man why this was
and the woodcutter said:
"It is no use nor anything!"
Zhuangzi said:
"Because this tree is no use
it gets to live out its lifespan from Heaven."
When the master left the mountains
he was putting up in a friend's home.
The friend was delighted
and ordered a wild goose to be slaughtered and cooked (for the guest).
The servant boy asked:
"One of these wild geese can sing
the other cannot sing:
may I ask which one I should kill?"
The host said: "Kill the one who cannot sing!"
The next day
a disciple asked Zhuangzi:
The other day, that tree in the mountains
got to live out all the years assigned by Heaven,
and now that wild goose belonging to your host
How would you deal with this case?"
died because of it's uselessness.
Zhuangzi said with a smile:
"I'd place myself in-between usefulness and uselessness.
In-between usefulness and uselessness
may look fine but is not really the right thing
and thus one does not avoid entanglements that way.
When it comes to the riding on the Way and one's natural endowment so as to glide and roam alsong that is a different matter.
Unconcerned about being praised, unconcerned about being sworn at,
at one point a dragon, at another point a snake
one is transformed along the the times
and is always unwilling to act in one particular way;
at one point going up, at another point going down,
one measures things by the harmony they provide,
one keeps floating and roaming with the ancestor of all things.
He treats things as mere things and does not allow himself to be treated as a mere thing by things
and how, in this way, would he ever get entangled with this world?
This is the standard method of Shen Nong and of the Yellow Emperor.
When it comes to the essence of the things of this world,
and what is handed down as moral code, these work differently:
they join and then again they diverge,
they succeed and then again they are ruined,
they are sharp, then again blunt,
they are honoured, then again disputed,
they get somewhere, then again get to be a flop,
they are worthy, then again conspiratory,
they are worthless, then again fraudulent:
how can these ever be a certain and stable basis for anything?
It is so sad!
You, my disciples, take note of this:
there is only this realm of the Way and natural endowment.

and the inscription went like this:
"If you take this with your left hand then your right hand will be gone,
and if you take it with your right hand your left hand will be gone,
but if you take this you are sure to head the government of the world.'
Would you be capable of taking it?"
Marquis Zhaoxi said: "I would not take it."
Master Huazi said: / "Excellent!
From this angle, then,
your two arms are more important to you than the whole world,
and your person is also more important to you than the two arms of yours.
The state of Han is far less important to you than the world
and what you are now quarrelling
is again much less important to you than the state of Han
and yet you insist on making yourself miserable and to harm your life
so much that you fret and worry about not being able to get hold of it."
Marquis Zhao Xi said: / "Excellent!
Those who have tried to teach me lessons are many
but never have I got to learn about words of this calibre!"
Master Huazi may be said
to understand the relative importance of things.
The ruler of Lu had heard that Yan He was the kind of person who had 'attained to the Way',
and he sent someone to gain good-will with presents of precious silk currency.
Yan He maintained a humble cottage a a home,
wearing coars cloth clothes he was himself feeding his oxen.
When the emissary from the ruler of Lu arrived
Yan He received him in person.
The emissary asked: / "Is this the home of Yan He?"
Yan He replied: / "This is the home of Yan He."
The emissary presented polite gifts of silk,
and Yan He replied:
"You must have got misheard your orders
and as the emissary you'll be blamed,
you had make sure you are doing the right thing."
The emissary turned round,
he went back to make sure he was doing the right thing
then when he arrived again looking for Yan He
he was quite unable to find the man.
And so, men like Yan He
by no means dislike wealth and nobility just like that, / they just dislike it because value their lives.
Therefore it is said:
"The true essence of the Way
is in administering one's own person,
the marginal expendable part of it
is in running the state,
and the rotten remains of it / are in governing the world."
From this point of view
the achievements of a sovereign or of a king
are marginal to the tasks of the sage,
and that is because these are not a means to preserve one's person intact and to nourish one's life.
The gentlemen of this vulgar age
mostly expoe heir persons to danger and throw away their lives
in their pursuit of mere things:
is that not tragic!
When the sage takes an initiative
he will make sure of why it is he he moving
and why he is doing what he is doing.
No suppose we have a man
who takes the pearls of the marquis of Sui as a bullet to shoot at a sparrow a thousand spans up in the air:
his contemporaries will laugh at him.
Why is this?
Well, it is because what he expends is more important
that what he is aiming for.
Now as for life
how would this just only of the kind of importance as that of the pearls of the marquis of Sui?
At one stage, Master Liezi had fallen on hard times,
he looked plainly famished.
A stranger remarked on this
to a certain Zheng Ziyang and said:
"Lie Yukou
would seem to be a squire possessed of the way,
and he lives in your state, but he is destitute.
Could it be that you, my lord, are of the sort who do not look well after their squires?"
Zheng Ziyang then ordered an official to send him grain.
Master Liezi came out to greeet the messenger
he bowed twice, politely, and he refused the gift.
The messenger left
and when Master Liezi was inside his home again
his wife stared at him from a distance, beat her chest and said:
I have heard that wives and children of someone who is possessed of the Way
all have a happy and easy time
but as it is now we have this famished look.
The ruler had someone come by and present you with some food,
and you, Sir, refused the gift.
Surely, this course of events was just fate!"
Master Liezi told him, with a smile:
"It isn't as if the ruler knows me personally
on the basis of other people's say-so he sent me some grain,
and the next time round he might do is to charge me with a crime,
and that again will be because yet somebody else's say-so.
This is why I was not going to accept the gift."
In the event the people did indeed rebel and they killed Ziyang.
King Zhao of Chu lost control of his state
butcher Yang Yue
fled and followed behind King Zhao.
When King won back his state
he was going to reward those who had followed him into exile
but when is was butcher Yang Yue's turn to be rewarded
butcher Yue Yang said:
"When Your Great Majesty lost the state
I was a sheep butcher;
and when Your Great Majesty regained the state
I likewise returned to be a sheep butcher again.
So my 'rank' and 'emoluments' have already been restored to me
and there is surely no further need for any reward."
The ruler said: / "Use force on him!"
Butcher Yang Yue said:
"Your Majesty's loss of the state
was not my fault,
so I was not prepared to be executed for that;
Your Great Majesty's regaining the state
was no contribution of mine,
so I was not prepared to be rewarded for it.
The King said: / "Send him in for an audience."
Butcher Yue Yand said:
According to the administrative procedures of Chu
one obligatorily must give substantial rewards for great contributions
before one can get to be granted any audience.
Now my intellectual skills were not great enough to ensure the continue existence of the state
and my courage was not great enough to die at the hands of the enemy
When the armed forces of Wu entered Chu
I was afraid there would be trouble
and I fled the enemy,
and it wasn't as if I was particulalry following your Great Majesty.
Now Your Great Majesty
proposes to abandon administrative practice and in breach of agreements to grant me an audience,
but this would not be something that would gain me any positive renown in the world."
The King told Sima Ziqi:
Butcher Yang Yue is a person of humble station
but the justice of his pronouncements is highly admirable
Be so kind to promote him to a position of the third banner for me, will you?"
Butcher Yang Yue said:
Now the position of the third banner
I'm quit aware this status is higher than that of a vendor of mutton in the marketplace;
and the stipen of ten thousand zhong
I'm aware represents greater wealth than the income from being a sheep butcher.
And yet: how can I possibly crave rank and emoluments
when in so doing I cause my ruler to have the bad reputation of arbitrariness in the distributio of benefits?
I really am not prepared to accept your offer,
and it is my hope to return to my sheep butcher's stall."
And so in the end he did not accept the offered reward.
Yuan Xian lived in Lu
in a round mud hut,
The thatched root was of living grass (as these still are in many parts of Norway)
and his doors were of bitter fleabane, not covering everything,
a mulberry trunk served as a door pivot, / and (bottomless) jars served as the windows for his two rooms,
with hemp used to fill in the holes.
The roof above was leaking and and the floor was damp; / but there he sat in his prescribed pose accompanying his song on a stringed instrument.
Zigong rode a carriage with tall horses, / his inner clothes were purple silk and his outer garments were plain white,
his carriage was so broad that there was no room for it in the little byway,
but there he was, paying a polite visit to Yuan Xian.
Yuan Xian was sporting a patterned cap and loose sandals,
and supporting himself with a pigweed cane he answered the door.
Zigong said: / "Ah!
What is wrong with you?"
Yuan Xian responded:
""I am told
having no property is poverty
and studying without being capable of putting things into practice amounts to having something with one.
Now, I for my part am poor, but there is nothing wrong with me."
Zigong took a respectful step backwards, visibly embarrassed.
Yuan Xian smiled and said:
"In fact, to adapt to one's times and act on this basis
to form cliques and make friends on this bsis
to study so as to serve others,
to teach so as to serve one's own interest,
the pretense of morality
the public show of fancy carriages and horses,
these are things that I cannot bear to engage in."
Zengzi was living in Wey
wearing a coat of rough hemp, with nothing on top of that,
his face was swollen here and there
his arms and feet were chapped
He might go three days without using fire,
he might go ten years without having new clothes made,
When he was setting his cap straight the his (rotten) chin strap would snap,
when he pulled up his collar, the elbow would pop out of his sleeve,
when he pulled on his sandals its heels would break off:
Pulling along his sandals on his feet as he went he intoned the "Ode of the Shang"
so his sound filled out Heaven and Earth,
and it was as if sound emerged from metal or stone.
The Son of Heaven was unable to gain his services as a minister,
the feudal lords were unable to win his friendships.
And so he who is preoccupied with his aspirations will forget all about his physical appearance,
and he is preoccupied with his physical form will forget all about considerations of personal gain,
and he who has attained to the Way will forget all about his own mind.
Confucius said to Yan Hui:
"Come here, Hui!
Your family is poor and you have miserable place to live,
why don't you go ahead and find public employment?"
Yan Hui replied:
"Public employment is not my aim in life.
I've got a plot of land outside the city walls, fifty mou large,
that will suffice to feed me with thick congee porridge,
and then I do have a plot of ten mou inside the outer wall
and that will suffice to supply me with silk and hemp;
strumming my zither will suffice to give me pleasure,
and what I learn about the Way of the Master
is sufficient to give me deep joy.
Public employment is not my aim in life."
Confucius suddenly had a melancholic expression on his face and said:
"Truly excellent, this way of thinking of Hui!"
I am told
'He who is modestly self-sufficient
will not entangle himself with considerations of personal profit;
He who has sorted out what it is live up to one's aspirations
will not be afraid to lose things;
he who has made a point of cultivating his inner life
will not be ashamed of being left without public appointment.
I have been preaching this for a long time
but it is only on the occasion of Hui that I have got to see what it was that I had been preaching,
this is my gain from all this."
Prince Mou from Zhongshan told Zhanzi:
"Physically residing by the rivers and by the sea
but with your mind being preoccupied by what is going on under city towers of the capital of Wei,
how does that feel?"
Zhanzi said: / "I give priority to my life,
and when one gives priority to life then one give less priority to one's personal profit."
Prince Mou of Zhongshan said:
I may understand this, / but I cannot quite win the better of myself on this issue."
Zhanzi said: / "If you cannot win the better of yourself then follow your instincts.“
"But would that not have ill effects on the spirit?"
"If you cannot win the better of yourself
and you do not follow your inclinations in a forced way
this is called 'suffering serious damage',
someone who suffers serious damage
is never of the long-lived kind."
Mou from Wei
was a prince from a major power with ten thousand war chariots.
for him to live a hidden life in the craggy caves / was more difficult to do than it is for any ordinary squire;
although he did not quite attain to the Way
it may be said that he had ideas of his own (and was not blindly following general custom like everyone else).
When Confucius was in trouble between Chen and Cai
he went seven days without hot food,
and his cold gruel with greeneries had no grain in it.
He looked haggard indeed
but there he was strumming a zither and singing away in his home.
While Yan Hui was out and about picking vegetables
Zilu an Zigong were saying to each other:
"Our Master was chased from Lu twice,
he was made to return straight back from Wey,
they cut down a tree on him in Song,
he was in dire straights in Shang and in Zhou,
and he was besieged in Chen and Cai.
A murderer of our master would get away scot free.
and those who humiliate him are never stopped.
Singing his songs to string accompaniment, playing his zither:
the music never stopped.
Can a true gentleman be as shameless as this?"
Yan Hui did not know how to respond.
He went in to report about the matter to Confucius.
Confucius pushed aside his zither and heaved a profound sigh, saying:
"Our friends Zilu and Zigong are petty fellows.
Call them over, / I'll give them a word."
Zilu and Zigong went in
and Zilu said:
"Our behaviour may be said to have been because we were at our wit's end."
Confucius said:
"What are you proposing here!
When the true gentleman thoroughly grasps the Way that is called having a solid grasp tout court;
when he is at his wit's end with regard to the Way that is called being at one's wit's end tout court.
Now I am embracing the Way of benevolence and duty
and thus meet the catastrophies of the chaos of this world:
there is no 'being at one's wit's end' to talk of!
Thus when upon reflection one has found oneself not at fault
then, faced with problems one will not fail one's natural endowments.
When the severe cold season is upon us
when frost and snow fall on everything,
that is when I understand the splendour of the pine and the cypress.
In ancient times Duke Huan of Qi got to go to Ju,
Duke Wen of Jin got to go to Cao
the king of Yue got to go to Kuaiji.
The narrow escape in Chen and Cai / was a piece of good fortune for me."
Having spoken thus Confucius straightened up and reverted to his zither
and sang to his string accompaniment.
Zilu enthusiastically grasped a large shield and performed a dance to go with the music.
Zigong said:
"I had no idea that Heaven is high above
and that Earth is down below.
Those who, in ancient times, attained to the Way
were full of joy when they were in trouble
and they were also full of joy when they had made it.
What gave them this joy was not a matter of being in trouble or making it.
At the point when one had got the way
then being in trouble and making are all the same, they are (natural phenomena) like the cold and the hot seasons
the alternations of wind and rain.
Thus it is that Xu You was having a good time on the northern shores of the River Ying
and Gong Bo made it in Gongshou.
When Shun was ceding the world to his friend Beiren Wuze
Beiren Wuze said:
"What an odd fellow our chief Shun is, basically:
lives in the ditches of the countryside
and then turns up at Emperor Yao's gate.
And as if this was not enough
insists on landing me with his dishonourable bureaucratic fiddles!
I would consider it as shameful to go to see him."
Having said this he threw himself into the Qingling Chasm.
When Tang was about to launch a formal attack on the tyrant Jie
he relied on Bian Sui for strategic advice.
Bian Sui said: / "This is beyond my competence."
Tang asked: / "Who'd be qualified, then?"
He said:
"I have no idea!"
Next, Tang was going to rely on Wu Guang for strategic advice.
Wu Guang said: "This is beyond my competence."
Tang said: / "Whom do you consider as competent for this?"
He said:
"I have no idea."
Tang asked: / "What about Yi Yin?"
Wu Guang said:
"He is a powerful personality, and he is prepared to put up with all sorts of shit.
But I have no idea about anything else about him.
So it was together with Yi Yin that Tang ended up launching his formal attack against Jie
and when he had one the battle against him
he proceded to offer the government of the world to Bian Sui.
Bian Sui said:
"When you were attacking Jie
you were consulting me
and that must have been because you considered me as a thug;
after you have defeated Jie you are ceding the government of the world to me
and that must be because you consider me greedy.
I have been born into this chaotic world
and now as a person with orientation concerning the Way
you turn up the second time to try and land me with your dishonourable bureaucratic fiddles
I don't have the patience to listen to this all the time."
And having said this he threw himself into the River Chou where he died.
Next Tang was going to cede the throne to Wu Guang and said:
"Intellectuals do the planning
the military create realities,
the benevolent maintain the standards:
that was the the way of the ancients.
So why are you not allowing yoursel to be established as a successor?"
Wu Guang declined, saying:
"Removing one's leader
is not in accordance with righteousness;
getting the people killed
is not in accordance with benevolence;
For others to be exposed to problems
and for oneself to profit from this
is not in accordance with moral integrity.
I have heard it said:
"For what is not one's duty
one does not accept the salary;
In a generation when the Way does not prevail somewhere
one does not enter the relevant territory.'
(I will not enter your territory,) even less allow myself to be given high honours!
I could not bear tohave to see you over a long period of time."
Having said that he took a stone on his shoulders
and drowned himself in the Lu River.
Formerly, when the Zhou were rising,
there were two squires who lived in Guzhu,
these were Bo Yi and Shu Qi.
The two said to each other:
"We understand there is a man in the West
who looks like someone possessed of the Way
let us go and see what he is like."
When they got to the southern foot of Mount Qi
King Wen had already died, / and when King Wu heard about them
he sent Shu Dan to have a meeting with them
and to make a contract with them:
"Your salary level will be raised by two levels
and you will take up office at the First Level.'
The contract to be confirmed with blood sacrifice and to be formally buried.
The two men looked at each other and smiled:
"Ah!
How very odd!
This is not what we deem to be the (true) Way.
In ancient times when Shen Nong was in charge of the world
he performed the timely sacrifices and showed perfect diligence in every way:
but he did not pray for his own happiness.
In his relations to other people
he showed loyal devotion and good faith and sorted everything out perfectly:
but he made no demands (for himself).
He delighted in joining the administration and even to run the administration;
he delighted to join government and even to run the government:
but he did not, at the cost of other people's ruin achieve success for himself,
and did not elevate his oen status at the cost of other people's devaluation.
Just because he hit the right moment (for becoming Emperor) he did turn this to his personal profit.
Now when the Zhou noticed the misrule among the Yin
they are in a great hurry to work on proper administration and government
conniving with those above
and bribing those below,
relying on military might maintaining their authority,
cutting up sacrificial animals and entering contracts to establish their good faith
they show off their public actions to please the masses,
with murderous campaigns they fight for their profit
and this is to overturn misrule and replace it with violence.
I have heard that the squires of old
when they chanced upon well-ordered times
did not shun their duties,
and when they hit upon times of misrule
did not use irregular means to hang on (in the system of government).
Now the world is passing a dark age
the natural endowments of the Zhou (themselves) are in decline.
Instead of lining up with the Zhou and thus defiling our persons
it will be better to get out of their way so as to maintain the integrity of our public conduct."
The two masters went to the Shouyang Mountain
and there they starved themselves, and they died there.
Now when it comes to Bo Yi and Shu Qi
their attitude towards wealth and status.
If they can help it, they definitely would refuse to rely on these things.
They raised their moral standards and they ensured their actions were excellent:
delighting in their aspirations only
they did not engage with their (deplorable) age.
These were the moral standards of these two squires.
Confucius and Liuxia Ji were friends,
and Liuxia Hui's younger brother happened to be Gangster Zhi.
Gangster Zhi had 9 000 armed followers
and he rampaged across the world
ravaging and terrorising the feudal lords
tunnelling his way into houses, unhinging doors,
driving off other people's oxen and horses
taking away people's wives and daughters;
greedy for gain, oblivious of their relatives,
without any regard for their parents or brothers,
and failing to offer due sacrifices to their ancestors.
Whenever they were passing by a district town
the big states made defensive arrangements with their walls
and in the small states people took refuge in their fortified compounds,
and the whole population found him insufferable.
Confucius said to Liuxia Ji:
"As a father
one must be capable of disciplining one's children,
and as an elder brother
one must be capable of instructing one's younger brothers,
and if a father is incapable of disciplining his sons
and an elder brother is incapabe of instructing his younger brothers
then there is no proper respect for the family relations between fathers and sons, or elder brothers and younger brothers.
Now when it comes to you, Sir,
you are the most talented squire of this age,
but your younger brother is the Gangster Zhi
who causes harm to the world,
but you are incapable of educating him properly.
I take the liberty to feel ashamed on your behalf,
and I beg permission on your behalf, Sir, to go along and persuade him to mend his ways.
Liuxia Ji said:
"You, Sir, maintain that a father
must be capable of disciplining his sons,
and that an elder brother
must be capable of instructing his younger brothers.
(That is all very well.) But if a son refuses to listen to his father's discipining words,
and if the younger brother refuses to accept his elder brother's instructions
then even with the arguments of someone like you, Sir,
then what is one to do?
Moreover, it is part of Zhi's character
that he has a mind like a bubbling spring,
a mind like a whirling wind,
a physical strength sufficient to parry any enemy.
and aways has arguments sufficient to make anything wrong appear right.
If you adhere to his thinking he will be fine,
and if you go against his thining he will be furious.
He easily comes to mortify people with his pronouncements.
You better not go, Sir!"
Confucius did not take this advice.
With Yan Hui serving as his driver
and with Zigong as his right-hand assistent
he went to visit Gangster Zhi.
Gangster Zhi, at that point, was just resting his armed disciples south of Mount Taishan
and he had minced human liver, and he was regaling himself on this dish.
Confucius got down from his carriage and moved forward,
meeting the butler he said:
"I'm Confucius, a man from the state of Lu,
and I have heard about the high moral standards of the generalissimo."
Respectfully he twice bowed his obeissance to the butler,
and the butler went inside to pass on the message.
Gangster Zhi, hearing about this,
flew into a great rage.
with eyes glistening like bright stars
and with his har standing up against his official hat
he said:
"Is that this notorious fraud, full of artifice, from the state of Lu, Kong Qiu(, or something)?
You go and tell him this on my behalf:
'You cook up propositions, make up talk
for no good reason you praise the civil and the military vitues,
you wear these official hats with their tree-braching structure,
you wear these girdles taken from the ribs of dead oxen,
you are full of elaborate formulations and of spurious explanation,
never doing your stint in the fields, you eat your full
never weaving any cloth, you wear your clothes,
swaggering your lips, clacking your tongue
you just make up right and wrongs left right and centre,
so as to confuse the rulers in this world.
You prevent the squires of this world from getting back to the basics,
to put up a fake pretense of filial piety and brotherly care,
and you find your greatest happiness in being appointed marquis and becoming rich and noble.
Your crimes are are great and they are extremely serious.
Off with you! Fast!"
And tell you what: if you don't,
I'll add your liver to my delicacies for this lunch!'"
Confucius returned this message
"By good fortune I have made your brother's acquaintance
and it is my fervent hope to pay you me deepest respects, 'viewing no more than you shoes below the curtain'."
When the butler again passed the message
Gangster Zhi said:
"Get him in here!"
Confucius shuffled forward
avoiding to sit down on the mat for him, he turned round and hurried some steps back
then he twice bowed obeissance to Gangster Zhi.
Gangster Zhi was still in a rage:
spreading out his legs in all directions
leaning on his sword, he just stared straight ahead,
with a roar was like that of a nursing tigress
he roared:
"Well, my friend: step forward!
If what you put forward
is to my liking you will live
and if it is not to my liking you will die."
Confucius said:
"I am told
that altogether there are three natural endowments in this world:
to be born and then to grow tall,
to be handsome, matchlessly,
so that the young and the adult, the noble as well as the humble
are pleased to look at you,
that is the highest natural endowment.
One's understanding encompassing Heaven and Earth,
the ability to argue competently about each thing in the world,
that is the middling natural endowment.
being audacious and decisive,
gathering the masses around one, and naturally leading armed forces
that is the lowest of the natural endowments.
As a matter of principle, everyone who has any one of these kinds of natural endowments
is qualified to act as a ruler, and to refer to themselves as The Bereaved One(, as only rulers are).
Now you, generalissimo, combine all these three natural endowments
you are eight feet two inches tall,
there is a glow on your face and in your eyes,
your lips are like lively cinnabar,
your teeth are like perfectly aligned seashells,
your tone of voice is in perfect tune with the standard pitch known as huangzhong,
and your name is - Gangster Zhi.
I take the liberty to feel ashamed on your behalf, and I would not have chosen that name.
But if you, my generalissimo are inclined to listen to me
then I beg to go as your emissary to Wu and Yue,
in the north to go as your emissary to Qi and Lu,
in the east to go as your emissary to Song and Wey,
in the West to go as your emissary to Chu,
and I will get all these to build a Great Wall, several hundred leagues long,
I will establish an administrative centre with several hundred thousand inhabitants,
I will get you honoured as a feudal lord,
and your reign will be last and begin again together with this world.
I will put a stop to military expeditions, and I demobilise the men under arms,
I will bring together and take good care of your brothers and brethren,
and together with these I shall sacrifice to your ancestors.
For these are the exploits of a sage and of a true man of talent,
and this is what everyone in the world is longing for."
Gangster Zhi continued in his great rage and said:
"Come forward, here, my friend!
The fact is that those who brought to heel with considerations of profit
or who can be made to change their minds with speeches
are all to be considered as just ill-informed vulgar ordinary people.
Now if I am tall and handsome,
and someone whom people are pleased to see,
then this is a matter of inherited natural endowments.
You, my friend, may not be full of praise for me
but don't I know this all by myself?
Moreover I have heard it said
that those who like to praise others to their faces
and the same people who also like to malign them behind their backs.
Now you, my friend, are telling me about a large wall and about the masses of people
and that is to try to bring me to heel through promises of gain,
and as if I were an ordinary fellow you are trying to groom me:
but how can you succeed in this in the long term.
Even the largest wall is not going to be larger than the whole world,
and Yao and Shun did rule over the whole world
but the descendants did not own any lands whatsoever;
Tang and Wu were established as Sons of Heaven,
but the later generations of their families were annihilated:
Now was not all that because the gains they went for were too great?
Moreoever, I have heard it said
that in ancient times birds and beasts were more, and humans were fewer.
and at that stage people were all perched in nests in order to keep away from the animals,
during the daytime the collected acorns and chestnuts
and in the evenings they perched on their trees.
That is why they were given the name 'the people of the Have Nests'.
In these ancient times the people had no ideas of wearing clothes:
in the summer they would gather firewood
and during the winter they would keep warm by the use of it.
That is why they were referred to as
'the people who know how to subsist.
During the times of Shen Song
people were dozing away their time
and rose to an easy way of life.
People knew their mothers
but they had no idea about their fathers,
they shared their living space with the milu deer,
they grew their food to eat
and they wove their clothes to wear.
and they never in a mood to harm each other.
This was the flourishing of ultimate natural endowments.
But the Yellow Emperor was incapable to realise these natural endowments:
with Chiyou he fought it out in the open countryside of Zhuolu,
and he caused the blood to flow over a hundred leagues.
Then Yao and Shun arose,
and they established ther cabinet of ministers
Tang banished his lord,
and king Wu killed Zhou.
From this time onwards
people were using the strong to oppress the weak,
they were using the majority to violate the minority
and since the times of Tang and Wu
the rulers were all adherents of scoundrels.
Now you are cultivating the way of Kings Wen and Wu
and you are in control of the public discourse in the world
to instruct the later generations
with your wide robes, and your minimal girdle,
your fake pronouncements and your contrived conduct
you misguide and confuse the ruling people in this world
hoping that way to find wealth and honour.
There is no bigger gangster than you!
Heaven knows why they do not call you Gangster Qiu, / and why they call me Gangster Zhi!

These six men,

This speech by which you were trying to convert me

then righteousness and integrity are the right thing (for you).

Explaining Swords
In ancient times King Wen of Zhao was fond of swords
and squires expert in swords crowded out the gates of the palace.
More than 3 000 retainers
were fighting it out in front of his gates
and more than a hundred men were injured, year by year.
The King could not get enough of all this.
This went on for three years:
the state declined
and the feudal lords were plotting against it.
Crown Prince Kui was upset by this
and he mustered his advisers around him, saying:
"Whoever is able to sway the King's thinking and stop the swordsmen / I shall reward with a thousand cash."
An adviser said: "Zhuangzi should be capable to do this."
So the Crown Prince sent someone to offer Zhuangzi a thousand cash.
Zhuangzi refused to accept the offer,
but together with the emissary
he went along to visit the Crown Prince and said:
"What are your instructions to me
since you are conferring on me a thousand cash?"
The Crown Prince said: / "I have heard that you, master, are an enlightened sage

and in due deference to you I have handed up to you a thousand cash, (of which you , of course have no need) for you to reward your travelling retinue with. [[This hyperbole is indeed much like what we see in Zhuangzi.]]
You, master, have refused to accept this
so how would presume to have any more to propose to you?"
Zhuangzi said:
"I understand that the reason you wish to employ me
is that you wish to put a stop to the predilections of the King.
Suppose on the one hand I try to persuade His Great Majesty
and go against his thinking, / and on the other hand I fail to satisfy you,
then I shall be mutilated and I shall die;
Then what practical use will the cash to me.
And suppose in on the one hand trying to persuade his Great Majesty, / on the other hand I do satisfy your wishes,
then I could demand anything in the state of Zhao (as a reward for my services) and would get it!
The Crown Prince said: / "Well, quite!
but (you see, the snag is that) my king receives in audience / are exclusively specialists in swordsmanship."
Zhuangzi said: / "I quite agree!
But then I'm quite good at swordsmanship."
The Crown Prince said: / "All right! / But the specialists in swordsmanship my king agrees to see
all have tousled heads and bristling beards,
dangling caps and odd tassels
clothes that are short cut behind,
they have staring eyes and have a hard time expressing themselves,
before the King likes them!
And now you, you are bound to wear Confucian garb when you pay your visit to the king
and this whole business will go greatly awry."
Zhuangzi said: / "L"et me sort out my swordsman garb!
Having sorted out his swordsman's garb for three days
he then went to visit the Crown Prince
and the Crown Prince then took him along to see the King.
The kind, having unpacked his sharp sword was waiting for him.
Zhuangzi entered the palace gates without the obligatory shufffle
and when he saw the king he failed to bow.
The king said:
"What do you wish to instruct me in
so you get the crown prince clear your access?"
Zhuangzi said: "I am told that your Great Majesty is fond of swords
and so I have come to see you about swords(manship)."
The king said: / "Well then: what is it that your sword is capable putting a stop to and controlling?"
Zhuangzi said:
"This sword of mine
will kill a man every ten paces,
over a distance of a thousand leagues,
without me having to stop the progress.
The king was greatly impressed
and he said:
"You are peerless in the world!"
Zhuangzi said:
"As a specialist in swordsmanship
one makes a show of insufficiency,
opens up to be taken advantage of,
is the last to let fly,
and the first to make one's hit.
I hope to get to give you a sample."
The king said:
"Master, you may withdraw to your hostel.
Await my orders before you put on your show. I shall be asking for you.
The king then set up his swordsmen squires against each other for seven days in a row
the dead and the wounded were in the sixties,
and he ended up with five or six men
whom he ordered to come to his presence, swords in hand,
and then he summoned Zhuangzi.
The king said:
"On this day we shall try to make these squires of swordsmanship cross their swords."
Zhuangzi said:
"I have been looking forward to this for a long time.
The king said: / "The piece you will be using,
how long is that?"
Zhuangzi said:
"Any piece I carry will be fine.
However, I have three swords,
and it is up to Your Majesty which one to use.
But let me first speak before the trial starts."
The king said: / "Well, in that case I hope to hear about those three swords of yours."
Zhuangzi said:
"I have a sword for a Son of Heaven,
I have a sword for a feudal lord,
and I have a sword for a commoner.
The king said:
"What is the sword for a Son of Heaven like?"
Zhuangzi said:
"The sword for a Son of Heaven
has the valley of Yan and the Stone Wall as its point,
the states of Qi and Dai are its blade,
Jin and Wey are its spine,
Zhou and Song are its handguard,
Han and Wei are its hilt.
This sword is wrapped by the Four Barbarians,
and it enveloped by the four seasons;
it is tied in by the Bo Sea,
and it is girdled by Mount Chang;
it is controlled by the the Five Agents,
and it is put in place by punishments and generosities;
it is opened up by Yin and Yang
it is maintained in shape by spring and autumn
and it proceeds by autumn ad winter.
This sword, when you move it straight forward nothing will survive further ahead,
when you lift it up nothing will survive further up
if you press it down nothing will survive further down,
if you wield it in circles nothing will survive anywhere near it.
Above, this sword cuts right through the drifting clouds,
below, it cuts right off the guidelines of Earth.
Once this sword is deployed
it will unite the feudal lords
and all the world will submit.
This is the sword for the Son of Heaven."
King Wen, bewildered, did not know what to do with himself,
and he said:
"What is the sword for a feudal lord like?"
Zhuangzi said:
"The sword for a feudal lord
has squires with a sense for valour for its point,
and it has squires of moral purity for its blade;
it has worthy squires as its spine
and it has loyal sagely squires as its handguard;
it has champions and heroes as its hilt.
This sword, when thrust forward nothing survives in front of it,
when lifted up likewise nothing survives above it;
when pressed down nothing survives below it
and when whirled about nothing survives anywhere near it
Above it models itself on round Heaven
so as to conform with the Three Lights;
below it models itself on square Earth
thus following the Four Seasons;
in between the two it brings harmony to the thinking of the people
so as to bring peace to all the lands of the world.
Once this sword is used
that will be like the blows of thunder and lightning,
within the Four Boundaries
everyone will obediently submit and follow the ruler's commands.
This si the sword for a feudal lord."
The king said:
"What, then, is the sword for a commoner like?"
Zhuangzi said:
"The sword of a commoner
Above, that sword lops off necks
below it slices up livers and lungs.
That sword for a commoner.
is no different from fighting cocks:
one fine morning their lives are finished,
and they are no use for government matters.
Now Your Great Majesty occupies the throne of the son of Heaven,
but you are all after the swords for a commoner:
I take the liberty to find this too slight for your needs."
The king thereupon dragged Zhuangzi up into the palace:
The chief butler served up a meal
but the king passed everything on three times.
Zhuangzi said:
"Your Great Majesty should sit down quietly and settle his spirits!
The matter of the swordsmanship memorial is finished.
So then king Wen refused to leave his dwelling for three months in a row
and all his squires specialised in swordsmanship died sudden deaths: on the spot!
As Confucius was wandering about in the Balck Tent Forests
he sat down to rest by the Apricot Altar.
His disciples were reading aloud from their books.
Confucius was intoning songs to his own string accompaniment, and he strummed his zither
but before he had got through even half of his song
there was an old fisherman
who descended from his boat and came along:
his temples and eyebrows, linked up together, were all white,
he had let down his hair, and was waving about his sleeves
and thus walked up from the shore
then at some distance from the firm land he stopped
he rested his left hand on his knee
and supported his chin with his right hand to listen to what was going on.
When the song was finished
he waved Zigong and Zilu over towards him
and the two men were both ready to answer any questions.
The stranger pointed at Confucius and said:
"What is that man over there all about?"
Zilu replied politely: / "That's a true gentleman from Lu."
The stranger asked what family lineage he belonged to.
Zilu politely replied:
"He belongs to the family lineage of the Kong."
The stranger asked: / "And what's the trade of the Kongs?"
Before Zilu resonded
Zigong politely replied:
"The Kong family
are by nature devoted to loyal devotion and good faith,
personally they practice benevolence and duty,
he adorns rituals and music,
codifies human relations,
so that, upwards, he shows loyal devotion to the ruler of his time
downwards he works on education to for the proper lining up of the people. (=濟民？？？）
and in these ways he is trying to be of benefit to the world.
This is what Mr Kong is all about."
The old fisherman went on to ask further: / "But is he the lord over a territory."
Zigong said: / "No, he isn't."
"Is he an assistant to a feudal lord or a king?"
Zigong said: / "No, he isn't."
The stranger then turned round with a smile
and as he walked off:
'He's benevolent enough,
but I'm afraid he won't get out of this with his person intact:
he is troubling his mind and labouring his body, and all this witht he result that he is endangering what is genuine in him.
Alas!
How far remmoved he is from the true Way."
Zigong turned back
