they make things flourish, and they nurture and store them,
having mainly in mind the old and the weak, the orphans and the widows,
providing for all what they need:
such is the principled care for the people.
How well the men of old provided all these things!
Living up to the divine luminaries,
reaching the purity of Heaven and Earth;
nourishing all creatures,
bringing harmony to the world.
Their generosity reached the hundred clans
and they were clear about the basic techniques involved;
they were meticulous about minor regular measures
in all the six directions, and during the four seasons;
small things and large, subtle things and gross
their regular procedures applied everywhere.
Their clear insight was in those techniques and minor measures
and these old administrative methods were handed down from generation to generation, many of which still survive.
As far as things are in the Odes, the Documents, the Rituals, and the Music,
the squires from Zou and from Lu
and the sash-bearing masters were many
who are capable of explaining these.
The Odes guide one's aspirations,
the Documents guide one's undertakings,
the Rituals guide one's implementation
the Music guides the harmony of the whole,
the Changes guide Yin and Yang,
and the Annals (of Lu) guide the naming and division of labour:
these techniques while spread through the world
were established in the central states,
and the scholars of all sorts of denominations will refer to them from time to time.
There is great misrule in this world,
worthies and sages have no clear insight,
the Way and people's natural endowments are not in accord.
Everybody tends to take hold of one thing
investigate and and decide themselves to prefer that thing.
It is like ears, eyes, nose and mouth
all specialising in certain features,
and being unable to take each other's place.
this is like all the families having each their special skills
and all having something they are good at,
and on their occasions they do have their uses.
But this being so,
they are not what is needed, they are not comprehensive.
If as a paroquial squires.
they set themselves up as judges of what is beautiful in Heaven and Earth
and they break up the principles that govern all the things of the world,
run their investigations into the perfection of the ancients,
only few of them are capable of addressing all that is beautiful in Heaven and Earth
and to give expression to its supernatural facets.
Therefore the Way of the internal sage and external king
is obscure and not clear,
it is repressed and does not freely develop.
The men of this world
each have their proper desires
and for that they take themselves as the standard.
How tragic
that all the families sally forth
but never stop to think:
in this way they are bound never to find together.
Our latter-day scholars
have no eyes, unfortunately, for the purity of Heaven and Earth.
The great overall unity of the ancients,
and the techniques of the Way are torn apart by everyone.
Not to allow later generations to become extravagant,
not to be wasteful in regard of the things of this world
not to make a show of precise techniques and regulations
so as to line oneself up in accordance with the explicit standards
and to guard against the urgent problems of the time:
among the 'techniques of the Way' of the ancients there are those that consist in these points.
Mozi and Qin Huali got wind of these ways of thought
and they were pleased with them,
but in practising precepts they went to excess,
and in implementing interdictions they followed their rules more than reasonable.
The composed "Against Musical Performances"
and another piece they called "On Moderating the Use of Resources".
Throughout their lives they never sang any songs,
and they did not wear mourning for the dead.
Mozi advocated universal care for all and universal benefitting everyone,
and he opposed violent conflict,
his Way (basic concern) was to avoid anger.
In addition he was in favour of broad perspective in study.
While not openly distancing himself from them
he was not in accordance with the Former Kings
and he worked towards the destruction of their ritual and musical precepts.
The Yellow Emperor had his "Xian Puddle"
Yao had his "Great Chapter"
Shun had his "Great Shao",
Yu had his "Great Xia"
Tang had his "Great Havest",
King Wen had his "Piyong" music,
and King Wu together with the Duke of Zhou produced the "Call to Arms".
The funeral rituals of the ancients
had specific rules for the noble and the base
superiors and inferiors were properly ranked,
and the inner and outer coffins of the Son of Heaven had seven layers,
for the feudal lords there were five layers
for the dignitaries there were three layers
and for ordinary squires there were two layers.
Now Mozi made an independent point of never singing any song throughout his life
and of not wearing mourning for the dead.
The paulownia coffin was to be just three inches thick
and there was to be no outer layer:
this he constituted as his standard method.
Using this he taught others
but I'm afraid he did not take good care of others;
using these standard methods he conducted himself
but he certainly did not take good care of himself.
I will not complete do down the way of Mozi,
but all the same
on singing songs, he is against singing songs
on public wailing (at funerals), he is against public wailing,
on the matter of music, he is against music:
is such an attitude actually appropriate?
In matters of his life he is meticulous,
in matters of death he is stingy;
his way was too half-hearted
causing people to worry,
causing people to become gloomy.
The conduct he recommendds is hard to carry out
and I'm afraid it cannot be deemed to be the Way of a sage.
He reverses the mindset of everyone
and no one can put up with this.
Even if Mozi in particular is capable of undertaking this course of action that he recommends
how does that matter to the world?
Deviating from everyone
he is far from true kinghood.
Mozi commends his way saying:
"In ancient times when Yu hemmed in the Great Flood
and opened up the rivers of the land
and linked them to the lands of Four Barbarians,
and the Nine Provinces
there were three hundred famous rivers
three thousand tributaries
and and untold number of minor streams.
Yu was in person carrying the bags and wielding the plough, and nine times he visited all the rivers of the world,
there was no hair on his shins
there was no hair on his calves
his bathing was in the violent rains,
his combing was done by the stormy winds,
and (in this way) he established all the states of the world.
Yu was a grat sage,
but he wore out his physical body for the world in such a manner."
And Mozi got the majority of the Mohists
to make jackets with corse cloth as their garment
and to make clogs and hemp sandals their formal dress.
They never rested, day or nibht
and thought it to be the ultimate achievement to impose hardship on themselves.
He said:
If we are incapable of acting like this
then ours is not the Way of Yu:
we do not deserve the name of a Mohist."
The disciples of Xiangli Qin
the adherents of Wuhou,
The southern Mohists, like Ku Huo, Ji Chi, Deng Lingzi and their ilk
all recite the 'Mohist Canon'.
although their competing readings are all different.
They call each other Dissident Mohists.
They insult each other with disquisitions on the hard and the white
they respond to each other with topsy-turvy formulations.
Their Grand Master they consider as a sage
and they wish they could serve in this function
hoping thereby to lay out the course for future generations:
and down to the present time they have never ceased to do this.
Mozi and Qin Guli's ideas were along these lines
but their actions, on the other hand, were not at all:

they set about forcing the Mohists of the later generations / so they absolutely had to wear themselves out to the point where there was no hair left on their thights, no down on their shins / just urging each other on and on.
This was the the finest variety of misrule
and the most inferior variety of good governance.
All the same
Mozi was in truth the most splendid figure in the world.
He was determined to try his best but did not succeed,
Even as he was shrivelling up with old age he never gave up.
A man of talent, indeed, wasn't he!
He never got entangled with the vulgar crowd
and he never made things look better than they are;
he was not callous in relation to others
and he was never resentful of the many.
He wished for peace in the world
preserving the lives of the common people,
and as long as the nurture of himself and of others
was sufficiently guaranteed he wanted no more:
with this train of thought he purified his mind.
So as for the ideologies of the ancients there were those who focussed on this.
Song Xing and Yin Wen learnt about this way of thinking
and were pleased with it
and the produced the Flower Mountain caps to demonstrate their commitments.
In handling the things of this world
they took the dismissing of untrammelled excess as their starting point
and they talked about the (empathetic) range of the heart
introducing for the term "the heart going forth (beyond its narrow self-centered perspectives),
with their congenial nature they were good company
and worked towards concord within the Four Seas:
from all their hearts they desired to establish this concord as the main thing.
Being humiliated they did not find disgraceful
as they went about saving the common people from violent strife.
They proposed the interdiction of aggressive warfare, and they were indeed advocating the abolishment of armed force,
and wanted to save the world from armed conflict.
With this message the traversed all the world:
those above they persuaded and those below they instructed.
Even if the world did not opt for their ideology
they kept going on and on about it, never giving up
and so the world went around
"Above and below people are fed up with them
but they keep imposing themselves on us."
Be that as it may:
they were going on too much about others
and showed too little concern for themselves,
as when they were saying: "All we need, essentially, is for you to provide five bushels of rice, that will be enough!"
Their leaders did not get enough to eat
and their disciples may have gone really hungry
but they never forgot the focus on the state of the world
and never stopped, day and night,
saying things like:
"We absolutely must get to make them all survive!"
What overambitious plans these squires, saviours of the world have!
The say:
"The true gentleman does not engage in ponderous enquiries
and he does lend his person to the service of mere things."
They considered that whatever was not of benefit to everyone
it would be best to let alone rather than try to understand clearly,
the interdiction of aggressive warfare and the abolition of armed forces
they considered the external point
the essential desire for moderation and temperance
they considered the inward point.
In small matters or small, subtle matters or gross
what their action was going for was the reaching of these points, and it went to further.
Being public-spirited and not faction-minded:
considering everyone as interchangeable and never working for special interests,
being decisive, without one overall aspiration
following one's passion for things and not considering alternatives
paying no attention to careful reflection
making no plans for an understanding of things
making no considered choice in relation to thigns
but going along with them:
there are those in antiquity who made it their ideology to focus on this:
Peng Meng, Tian Pian, Shen Dao learnt about this tradition and were pleased with it.
They considered all things of the world to be on a par, and that was their main thesis.
They said: / "Heaven can cover things / but it is incapable of supporting it;
Earth can support things, / but Earth is incapable of covering them;
the Great Way is capable to encompass things, / but it is incapable of discriminating between them.
They thought they understood that all things are acceptable in their own way
and they are all unacceptable, again each in their own way.
Therefore they say:
"If one selects one thing rather than another, one's vision is not comprehensive,
if one teaches any particular doctrine one has not reached the ultimate point
the true Way is the one that leaves out nothing (responds to everything at the same time)."
Therefore Shen Dao rejected knowledge and discarded his Self,
devoting himself to the guideline of the inevitable.
He makes a point of conforming in every way to things
and deems that to be the underlying principle of their way.
He says: "To 'know' is not to understand."
His strategy was first to devalue knowledge and only then to poke fun at it. [天下篇四種 p. 42]
He did not give a damn refused all public responsibilities
and just laughed at everybody respecting the 'worthies'.
He completely let himself go, recognised no recommended conduct for himself
and disapproved all the sages under the sun.
he hammers it, kocks it: the corners are knocked off:
he twists and tumbles along with the things of this world
rejects what is accepted and sides what is rejected.
and God knows how he gets away with it all.
Never takes lessons from knowledge or careful thought,
blissfully unaware of what comes before and after his action
he just sallies forth, that is all.
Only when pushed to it will he take action;
only when pulled will he move along;
like the turning of the whirlwind
like the whirling of feathers
like the grindstone following its course he follows his course,
keeping intact and without blame:
taking action or keepig still he remains without fault
and never gets guilty of any crime.
Why does he manage this?
This is because a creature that knows not what it is doing
will never suffer the disasters that ensue when a man builds up his Self:
he never suffers from the entanglements that follow from using one's intelligence,
in his initiatives or his failures to act he he will not offend against the regular pattern of things,
and that - incidentally - is why he is never praised throughout his life.
Therefore Shen Dao said;
"It is all a matter of becoming like those creatures without knowledge, that is all:
there is no use for worthiness and sagehood.
Those creatures without knowledge, like clods of earth, never lose the Way.
The big shots in this world join each other in laughing at Shen Dao, saying:
"The Way of Shen Dao
does not describe the conduct of a living person:
it is a matter of reaching the principles for a dead person
and so it happens that he is considered weird."
Tian Pian is also like this.
Having studied with Peng Meng
he obtained from his teacher what cannot be taught.
Peng Meng's teacher, in turn, said:
"The ancients who had attained to the Way
reached the stage where he deemed nothing right and where he deemed nothing wrong: that was all.
His mode was one of recalcitrance:
how is one to put it in words."
So these people were consistently opposed to others
They never gathered any crowd of adherents
and they never escaped from that 'lopping off the corners'.
What they called their Way wasn't in fact any Way at all
and what they asserted never managed to be other than wrong-headed.
So, Peng Meng, Tian Pien and Shen Dao had no understanding of the Way.
All the same, it would appear that they all were exposed to things to learn from.
What is basic they considered to be subtle
the physical things they considered to be crude reality,
to consider anything cumulative to be insufficient
to take one's place in serenity, all alone, with the spiritual intelligences:
among the ideologies of the ancients there were those who focussed on this.
Guan Yin and Lao Dan heard about this and were pleased with it.
They established their teachings on the basis of what is forever non-existent,
and guided it all by the notion of the Great One.
Meekness and humility they cultivated as their outward sign
empty receptiveness, and the avoidance of ruining the things of this world were the substantial features (of their teachings).
Guan Yin said:
"When one rests in one's Self
outward forms and things will become clear of themselves.
His actions will be like the flow of water,
his stillness will be like that of a mirror,
his responses will be that of an echo;
he is vacant, as if absent,
he is still, as if pure.
Being one with this Self he is in tune with things,
trying to get hold of this Self he will lose it. (See Yucong 1)
He never leads others, / and he consistently follows others.
Lao Dan said:
"Understand the male (in yourself)
sustain the female (in yourself)
and you become the gulley for the world (on which all brooks converge);
Understand innocence (in yourself),
sustain humiliation (from others,
and you will become the valley for the world.
Others may all opt for being first,
but himself he opts for coming last.
He said:
"Accept the dust and dirt of this world!"
Others may all opt for what is full (and assertive)
but himself he opts for what is empty (receptive:
He stores up nothing and therefore has more than he needs
vastly more, indeed, than he ever needs.
In his comportment / he is slow and never wasteful of his energy,
he is disengaged and laughs at skillful activism.
Others may all seek good fortunate affluence
he alone bends to circumstances to stay intact.
He said:
"By whatever means necessary avoid inauspicious activism!"
Depth of perspective he took to be basic
and economy of action he took as his rule.
He said:
"If you are hard, you will be broken,
if you are sharp, you will get blunted."
Consistently he made room for things,
and never found himself encroached upon by others.
He can be said to have reached the ultimate point.
Ah! Guan Yin and Lao Dan:
these were the veritable men of broad spiritual sweep in antiquity.
In their stillness they cut no shape (for others to attack),
in their adaptive transformations they offered not stable target.
Dead or alive,
Heaven and Earth are on a par with him
the spirits go out to join him.
Disorientated, where is he going?
Mindless, where does he reach?
All the things of the world throw their net over us
none of them deserves to be rallied to.
In ancient times there were those whose ideology was along these lines.
Zhuang Zhou heard about this way of thought and was pleased with it
using fictitious and outlandish explanations
as well as weird forms of speech
and uncircumscribed formulations,
at times being reckless, but never being partisan
he never viewed things from just one particular angle,
he considered the world to be sunk in a mire of impurities
and not to be in a state to be worth talking to.
By means of free-wheeling words he practised untrammelled indulgence
and his "repeated phrases" he considered the veritable message,
through his attributed words he broadened his literary range.
In his independent spirit he communed with Heaven and Earth,
and did not take the time to cut a figure among the creatures of this world.
He did not set himself up as a judge of right and wrong,
and he found his place among the common crowd.
His writings (authorship!!!) may be all over the place
but trundling along they never do any harm.
His prose may be irregular
but in their grandiose way they are worth contemplating.
These things, with their saturated spiritual substance have an unlimited quality.
Above he roams with the Fashioner of the Things of this World,
and below he associates with those who are beyond death and life
who are without beginnings nor ends.
When it came to the basics
he was comprehensive and innovative,
he was deep and unrestrained;
when it came to the ancestral sournce
he may be said to well-attuned and eage to follow right up (to antiquity).
All this may be true, / but in his response to tansformations
and his unravelling of things
his principles were inexhaustible
their realisation undergoes no fundamental change:
confused, yes! obscure, yes!
but one could never exhaust these.
Hui Shi was a man of many trades,
his books filled four carriages,
his Way contorted and screwed up,
this pronouncements uncentered
and the idea behind his investigation of things
was to say:
"Beyond the ultimately greeat there is nothing,
and that is called the Great One,
Inside the ultimately small there is nothing,
and that is called the Small One.
what has no volume
cannot be accumulated,
but it encompasses a thousand leages.
Heaven and Earth are equally low
mountains and marshes are level with each other,
as the sun reaches the zenith it starts settng.
as creatures are born they die.
Great sameness is different form small sameness:
this is called the small features of sameness and difference.
All things are the same, and they are also different:
this is called the large scale features of sameness and difference.
The southern regions are unbounded and yet they do have their limits;
Today one goes to Yue and some time ago one came there.
Interlocked rings can be detached from each other.
I know the centre of the whole world:
it is north of Yan and south of Yue.
Universally love all things:
Heaven and Earth are one complex structure.
Hui Shi considered all this the large-scale contemplation of the world,
and he understood the workings of sophists/debaters:
all the debaters of the world were pleased with him.
Eggs have feathers;
a chicken is three-footed;
Ying contains the whole world;
a dog may be deemed a goat;
horses lay eggs;
a toad has a tail;
fire is not hot;
mountains come out through the mouth;
wheels nowhere touch the ground;
eyes do not see;
signifying does not reach;
the ultimate is not detached;
the tortoise is longer than the snake;
the T-square is not sqare;
with the compass one cannot make a circule;
the chisel does not fit exactly onto the handle;
the shadow of a flying bird never ever moves;
fast as the barbed arrow is
there is a stage when it is neither moving nor at rest;
a whelp is not a dog;
a brellow horse and a black ox are three in number;
a white dog is black;
an orphan colt never had a mother;
a one-foot-long pole
if you cut off half of it every day,
you will not finish the operation in ten thousand generations.
The debaters responded along these lines to Hui Shi
and they never stopped doing that to the end of their lives.
and on every one of the world's things he had his explanations:
explaining without ever giving himself a rest,
mellifluous without end,
still he considered that too little
and to one's astonishment he added more of the same.
Going against others he deemed to be the substantial thing to do
and his desire what to establish a name for himself by defeating others:
as a result he was not on goo terms with others.
Weak in natural endowments
strong on mere things
his path was abstruse.
If from the point of view of the Way of Heaven and Earth one contemplates the capacities of Hui Shi
they were like those of a mosquito or a gnat:
in relation to the things of this world what use were they?
Now if one is fully competent in one direction, that still is acceptable
and one would say:
'Had he held the true Way in higher esteem
he would have been nearly there!'
But Hui Shi could not calm himself down by this one direction:
he spread himself across all manner of things in this world, indefatigably,
and in the end it was for his skills in disputation that he established a name for himself.
How tragic!
With the talents of a Hui Shi
to loaf about and never get anywhere,
to chase after everything there is in this world and never stop to think!
Such a man is shouting down his echo:
but like form and shadow they follow each other along!
How tragic!
Men like Huan Tuan and Gongsun Long
were out to add flourishes to people's minds,
they were out to change people's way of thinking,
they were capable to shutting up other people's mouths
but they were incapable of subduing other people's minds:
this is the natural limitation of the debaters.
Day after day Hui Shi used his knowledge to join other people's debates,
and in particular when he was together with the sophists of this world he put on astounding performances:
This is just about it (when it comes to Hui Shi.)
All the same, in Hui Shi's conversation
he deemed himself to be the most worthy of them all.
